description: Borrowed from Latin negotiatus, past participle of negotiari (“to carry on business”), from negotium (“business”) (Eng. usg. 1599), from nec (“not”) + otium (“leisure, ease, inactivity”).

verbs.description: negotiate (third-person singular simple present negotiates, present participle negotiating, simple past and past participle negotiated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To confer with others in order to come to terms or reach an agreement.
examples: "You are quite right in calling for negotiation. Indeed, this is the very purpose of direct action. Nonviolent direct action seeks to create such a crisis and foster such a tension that a community which has constantly refused to negotiate is forced to confront the issue."

entries.meaning: (transitive) To arrange or settle something by mutual agreement.
examples: We negotiated the contract to everyone's satisfaction.
The client and server computers must first negotiate a network protocol to be used.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To succeed in coping with, or getting over something.
examples: We negotiated the mountain track with difficulty.
Although the car was quite rickety, he could negotiate the curves very well.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To transfer to another person with all the rights of the original holder; to pass, as a bill.
(obsolete) To transact business; to carry on trade.
